abstract.text: A graphics renderer for creating PDFs.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You can use PDF renderers to create PDF files, without having to manage Core Graphics contexts.
To render a PDF:
Optionally create a
object to specify nondefault parameters the renderer should use to create its context.
Instantiate a
object, providing the dimensions of the output image and a format object. The renderer uses sensible defaults for the current device if you don’t provide format object, as demonstrated in
Choose one of the rendering methods depending on your desired output:
outputs the PDF in the form of a
object, and
saves the PDF as a file directly to disk.
Provide Core Graphics drawing instructions within the closure associated with your chosen method, as shown in
Optionally, you can create a multi-page PDF, using the approach shown in
Optionally, add links to your PDF to make navigation easy, as shown in
After initializing a PDF renderer, you can use it to draw multiple PDFs with the same configuration.
Create a PDF renderer, providing the bounds of the PDF page.

code: let renderer = UIGraphicsPDFRenderer(bounds: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 500, height: 300))

inlineContent.text: You can instead use one of the other
initializers to specify a renderer format (
) in addition to the bounds. This allows you to configure the underlying Core Graphics context with custom PDF document info. If you don’t provide a format, the renderer uses the
format, which creates a context best suited for the current device.

content.text: Creating a PDF with a PDF renderer

inlineContent.text: Use the

method to create a PDF with the PDF renderer you created above. This takes a block that represents the drawing actions. Within this block, the renderer creates a Core Graphics context using the parameters provided during renderer initialization, and sets this to be the current context.
Before issuing PDF drawing instructions, you must create a page with a call to either the
method or
method on the supplied

code: text.draw(in: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 500, height: 200), withAttributes: attributes)

inlineContent.text: The drawing actions closure takes a single argument of type
. This provides access to some high-level drawing functions, such as
through the
superclass.
This code uses a drawing method on
. If you want to create a PDF with more text, consider using
or
, both of which provide extensive text layout functionality.
The above code creates the following result:
Add multiple pages to your PDF through repeated calls to the
method on the
provided to the drawing block.

code: text.draw(in: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 500, height: 200), withAttributes: attributes)

inlineContent.text: Use the
method instead of the
method if you want to override the default properties for the new page.
This code creates a PDF with three pages, each of which contains the current page number as large text, as shown in the following image.
You can create internal links, known as destinations, in PDFs. A complete link has two components:
A named destination. This is a point on a PDF page. You create these with the
method on
A link region. This is a rectangle on a PDF page, which when tapped, instructs the PDF viewing app to jump to a specific named destination. You create these with the
method on
, providing the name of the destination to jump to, and the bounds of the active link region.
The following code demonstrates how to use destinations with a PDF renderer by showing how to create links that jump to the next page.

code: let nextPageRect = CGRect(x: 350, y: 250, width: 150, height: 40)
pageNumber.draw(in: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 500, height: 200), withAttributes: pageNumberAttributes)

inlineContent.text: This code adds large red labels that jump from the current page to the next page when clicked. Each page has a destination with names of the form
, positioned at the origin. The bounding box for the next-page label is the link to the destination on the following page.
The
and
methods on
use the underlying PDF coordinate space, which has its y-axis flipped with respect to the coordinate system used by Core Graphics. You can translate between the two using the
property on
, as shown in the code.
The above code results in the following PDF:

abstract.text: A Quartz 2D drawing environment.
Returns an affine transform that maps user space coordinates to device space coordinates.
A byte buffer in memory.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A graphics renderer for creating Core Graphics-backed images.
The drawing environment for an image renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of an image renderer context.
A graphics renderer for creating PDFs.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Creating a PDF with a PDF renderer

abstract.text: A closure for drawing PDF content.
Creates a new graphics renderer with the specified bounds and format.
Creates a PDF from a set of drawing instructions and returns it as a data object.
Creates a PDF from a set of drawing instructions and saves it to a specified URL.
The drawing environment for a PDF renderer.
Creates a named destination point in the current PDF page.
Marks the beginning of a new page in the PDF context and configures it using default values.
Marks the beginning of a new page in the PDF context and configures it using the specified values.
Creates a link rectangle in the current page that jumps the PDF viewer to the named destination when clicked.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a PDF renderer context.
An abstract base class for creating graphics renderers.
The base class for the drawing environments for graphics renderers.
Paints a rectangular area with the currently selected fill color.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a graphics renderer context.
Returns a format that represents the highest fidelity that the current device supports.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
